  LITM_CODE_OK = 0, LITM_CODE_NO_MESSAGE, LITM_CODE_BUSY, LITM_CODE_ERROR_MALLOC,
  LITM_CODE_ERROR_CONNECTION_OPEN, LITM_CODE_ERROR_BAD_CONNECTION, LITM_CODE_ERROR_NO_MORE_CONNECTIONS, LITM_CODE_ERROR_INVALID_BUS,

typedef struct _litm_envelope litm_envelope

``Envelope`` structure for messages

Parameters:
cleaner The ``cleaner`` function to use
routes The ``routing`` structure
msg The pointer to the message
Contains the pointer to the message as well as a ``routing`` structure used to deliver the said message to all bus which have at least 1 subscriber.

The client (ie. receiver of the envelope) must not tamper with the message (ie. msg) as it is shared with other client(s).

typedef struct _queue_node queue_node

Queue node - entry in a queue

Parameters:
msg,: pointer to the message
next,: pointer to the ``next`` queue_node entry

Function Documentation

litm_code litm_connect ( litm_connection **  conn  ) 

Opens a ``connection`` to the ``switch`` and returns a pointer to the connection reference

Parameters:
**conn pointer to connection reference

Definition at line 42 of file litm.c.

Here is the call graph for this function:

litm_code litm_disconnect ( litm_connection *  conn  ) 

Disconnects from the ``switch``

Once a client calls this function, no more access with the connection is permitted to any of the following functions:

  • litm_subscribe
  • litm_unsubscribe
  • litm_receive_nb
  • litm_send
  • litm_release

Be sure to release any message in the client's care before disconnecting.

Parameters:
*conn connection reference

Definition at line 58 of file litm.c.

Here is the call graph for this function:

void* litm_get_message ( litm_envelope *  envlp  ) 

Returns a copy of the pointer to the message.

Parameters:
*envlp the envelope from which to extract the pointer to the message
This function should be used instead of relying on the ``litm_envelope`` data structure.

** DO NOT** modify the message!

Definition at line 135 of file litm.c.

litm_code litm_receive_nb ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_envelope **  envlp 
)

Receives (non-blocking) from any ``bus``

See also:
litm_disconnect
Parameters:
*conn connection reference
**envlp the pointer to received envelope
Receive (non-blocking) function for clients

Note:
It is the responsibility of the client to _not_ use this function once a connection is closed.

Definition at line 96 of file litm.c.

Here is the call graph for this function:

litm_code litm_release ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_envelope *  envlp 
)

Releases an ``envelope``

See also:
litm_disconnect
Parameters:
*conn connection reference
*envlp the pointer to received envelope to release
Once the client has consumed the message ``contained`` in the envelope, the client **MUST** release it back to litm.

Release a message to LITM

This function should *ONLY* be used by client's as a result of finishing the processing of an envelope/message retrieved through ``litm_receive_nb''.

Definition at line 121 of file litm.c.

Here is the call graph for this function:

litm_code litm_send ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_bus  bus_id,
void *  msg,
void(*)(void *msg)  cleaner 
)

Send message on a ``bus``

See also:
litm_disconnect
Parameters:
*conn connection reference
bus_id the ``bus`` to send the message onto
*msg the pointer to the message
*cleaner the pointer to the cleaner function
If omitted, the default ``cleaner`` function will be free().

If an error occurs, it is the responsibility of the sender to dispose of the ``messages`` appropriately. If the operation went LITM_CODE_OK, then once all recipients are finished with the message, the ``cleaner`` will be called with the message pointer OR if ``cleaner`` is NULL, the message will simply be freed with free().

Definition at line 78 of file litm.c.

Here is the call graph for this function:

void litm_shutdown ( void   ) 

Shutdown

This function attempts to shutdown all the connection threads in a graceful manner. This function is blocking.
